page.title: 06BIRDS OF WELLS SALTMARSH
page.content: The northern edge of the survey area is an extensive Saltmarsh bordered by sand dunes and pine trees called East Hills. It is an important site for wintering birds. Some 1250 Brent Geese feed on the eel grass, and 1400 Shelduck have been recorded roosting on the sands during rough weather at sea. Internationally important are the number of Knot (up to 9000) that feed on Bob Hall's Sands. The winter of 1984/85 saw a roost of 9 Hen Harriers in the suaeda bushes. Breeding specialities include Little Tern (68) and Ringed Plover (18) and 650 pairs of Blackheaded Gulls also nest here. In addition to the regular visitors these marshes have everything a migrating bird needs when blown off course and Pied Flycatchers, Redstarts Whinchats and Warblers gain shelter.
